msgSnippet: Jon & Ewout: I am not so sure  the idea of a transliterating keyboard driver is a good idea.  It reminds me of training wheels on a bicycle.  When I was five,
messageBody:
Jon & Ewout:

I am not so sure  the idea of a transliterating keyboard driver is a good idea.  It reminds me of training wheels on a bicycle.  When I was five, I rode my bicycle for a year with training wheels attached to the rear wheel.  When my father finally took them off, we discovered I still did not know how to balance because the training wheels had kept me from  having to.  But after they came off, I learned to ride the same day.

I don't want to push this analogy too far, but just in the last few days after posting a few messages and texts in jerome, I have found my skill in typing with jerome has advanced  fairly quickly.  I still have a few letters I have to search for, but it will not take long before I will be able to type fairly easily in jerome.

I think it is best to write with Quikscript in mind rather than using some intermediate combination of letters which are then transliterated by a driver to produce the symbol you intend.   No one thinks of a "they" or "thaw" as "dh", and I feel it adds a needless level of complexity.  I believe very few people have actually tried to use jerome up to this point so no one has much experience with it.  I am a good touch typist and never look at the keyboard when I type.  I would assume, however, that it is probably more difficult to get used to the jerome keyboard mapping for a person who is not a touch typist since the Quikscript symbols do not appear on the keys.  Of course, the way one becomes a touch typist is by practice and watching the screen as one types.  So I believe anyone who is motivated can, with a moderate amount of practice, learn to type using the current jerome mapping.

Of course, in any touch typing, one should use the proper fingers on the appropriate keys, which requires the use of all eight fingers and one thumb.  I believe the average self-taught typist only uses three or four fingers so their hands are moving all over the keyboard, which makes it impossible to type quickly.  But there are innumerable typing programs, which can break them of this improper technique.  (I know:  it will difficult to tell someone to learn to type first, and then learn jerome touch typing.)  I am just voicing my opinion that it is better to touch type in jerome than it is to learn a series of alternate letter combinations representing one symbol, and the production of such a driver may lead to people not thinking with Quikscript in mind as they type.  And how will that affect how they handwrite in Quikscript in their own daily lives.  My concern is that the production of such a driver may actually be a shortcut that is detrimental to these individuals learning and utilizing Quikscript in the long run and, thus, will be detrimental to the spread of Quikscript.

Note:  As an interesting historical aside, we have been stuck with the Qwerty keyboard since the early days of typewriters.  I read that this ordering of keys was decided upon due to the poor mechanisms of those typewriters:  if you activated two keys next to each other too frequently, the mechanism tended to jam.  The Qwerty keyboard is actually poorly designed for fast typing as the vowels, with the exception of "a" are not on the home key row.  Obviously, this makes no sense as the vowels are the most used letters and moving your fingers off the home row takes more time.  There is an alternative keyboard, Dvorak, which is designed more scientifically.  After a touch typist makes the transition to Dvorak, their typing speed increases approximately 20% just from the improved key positions.   Since touch typing involves a connection between the mind and the appropraite finger position on the keyboard, one cannot use both the Qwerty and Dvorak keyboard depending on which is present on a particular machine.  In tests it took approximately two weeks for a secretary to make the transition to Dvorak.  Once she had, she was no longer able to type quickly on a Qwerty keyboard.  This, coupled with the natural conservatism of businesses and people in general, explains the absolute dominance of Qwerty.  The inertia of the mass of people who touch type using Qwerty because that is what has always been available have prevented Dvorak from making any inroads on Qwerty.

Moving to another point:  the problem I see with the present keyboard mapping for jerome is that Jon set it up to match the present Shavian mapping on the theory, I believe, that some of the people interested in Shavian who had already learned the existing Shavian mapping would make the shift to Quikscript.  I do not see any evidence of that happening on any significant scale, and the current mapping is not as felicitous for jerome as it could be.

The letters which jerome shares with roman should be set up for the same keys as much as possible to aid the shift from roman to Quikscript   There are twenty-six letters on the keyboard,and with the use of the shift key, this gives us fifty-two positions for letters.  I believe we should avoid the use of keys currently used for punctuation and other symbols unless absolutely necessary.  As an example, "wholewheat" is currently mapped on the "tilde" key.   This is a long stretch for the left little finger and does not aid fast typing.  Because it is a key little used in roman typing, it forces me to look at the keyboard, which a touch typist does not want to do.

Shavian has no half-letters so the Shavian mapping did not have to take that issue into account.  Since Quikscript does use half-letters, it would make sense to me that those letters should be produced by using the shift key along with the same key that produces the whole letter.  Example:  "peep" mapped to "p", "half-peep" mapped to shift "p."  "Day" and "half-day" to be mapped the same way on "d" and shift "d."  And so forth.

Jon, how much trouble would it be to remap a revision of jerome to work better for Quikscript?  I assume that the dificult part in producing the font was setting up the letter shapes and that the key mapping was a relatively straight forward process.  Is this correct?  If we made such a revision available on Read_Alphabet, those people prefering the Shavian mapping could continue to use it, and those who prefer an optimized Quikscript version could use it.  The recepient of a communication will not care how it is mapped.   People migrating from the Shavian group to the Read_Alphabet group could use the mapping they were already familiar with.  Those who are totally new devotees of Quikscript could use the revised mapping.  If doing this remapping is not a vast amount of trouble, I will work on a remapping scheme to see how the mapping can be improved.  I would like to do this before I spend too much more time using the present mapping.

Aside:  I have been working on Hamlet's soliloquy in Senior Quikscript.  The half-letters are working very well.  I also believe that some of the letters that I thought needed additional work look fine when a 12 point font is used.  In general, I am very pleased with jerome.

Sorry this was so long.   Sometimes I get started and can't seem to stop.

All the best to everyone,

Paige Gabhart
 
 

Jon Zuck wrote:

 Wow, Ewout!  This sounds excellent.  Is there anyone who can create such a
driver for us?

It sure would make using QS a lot easier.
 

Shalom v'Tovah,

Jon
http://surf.to/frimmin
